Print This Page
Cambridge City
MA

Resolution
RES 2024 #299

Condolences on the death of Barclay Tittmann.

Information

Department:City Clerk's Office, PTSponsors:Councillor Paul F. Toner
Category:Death Resolution

Attachments

Version History
  1. Printout

Body

WHEREAS:

The City Council was deeply saddened at learning of the death of Barclay Tittmann on November 12, 2024, at the age of 92; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay was the beloved husband of almost 68 years to Lucy Keith Tittmann; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay was the proud father of Eleanor, John, Robert, Sally, Anna and Edward, 15 grandchildren and one great-grandchild; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay was born in Rome, Italy, to Harold Hilgard Tittmann Jr., a career diplomat and World War 1 Veteran, and Eleanor Dulaney Barclay, spending most of his early years in Italy and Switzerland, before moving into Vatican City during World War II; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Attending I’Institut Le Rosey, a boarding school in Switzerland where he learned to ski, graduating high school in 1949 from Middlesex School in Massachusetts, Barclay graduated from Yale in 1953 with a degree in Humanities, the Arts and Letters; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay served in U.S. Naval Intelligence for several years before marrying Lucy Keith in May 1957 and moved with her to Edmonton, Alberta, where he worked various construction jobs and as a stockbroker; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

While in Canada, Barclay took classes toward a master’s degree in literature at the University of Alberta, decided to pursue a PhD at l’Université de Liège in Belgium, moving to Madid Spain to research a 14th-century Spanish Poet for his thesis, and finishing his thesis and earning his PhD in 1968 from Boston College; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay retired at age 71 after a long career that included teaching Spanish Literature at Boston College and Portfolio Management with Gardner & Preston, comparing the similarities where he researched and presented his findings; and later returning to teaching after retirement leading seminars on Don Quixote, Shakespeare and other literary topics at Harvard Institute for Learning in Retirement; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Taking classes at HILR, Barclay added German to his formidable language skills, which already included fluency in both French and Spanish, an ease with other romance languages, and proficiency in Russian; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

A lover of classical music and opera, Barclay wrote 13 musical plays for the Tavern Clbu, a social club focused on amateur theater where he was an active member for almost 40 years; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay’s brilliance was often underestimated due to his modest, ego-free demeanor, yet he had an extraordinary memory, recalling and understanding any event-personal, historical or current-discussing it in dept, while also showing genuine interest in others’ opinions, listening attentively, and never forgetting what was shared with him; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

An accomplished athlete, Barclay rowed varsity lightweight crew at Yale, a fearless skier of both downhill and cross-country, a strong and agile mountain climber, avid tennis and squash player, playing into his 80’s, swam in the Gulf of Maine while on the island of North Haven and a daily walker until 90; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay was a devoted family man who revered and adored his wife of 68 years, loved and cherished his children and grandchildren, had a dry sense of humor and a flawless, dead-pan delivery, seeing the humor in whatever was happening around him; and

 

 

WHEREAS:

Barclay, his peace, grace and acceptance of things he couldn’t change, will be sorely missed by all he touched and loved; now therefore be it

 

 

RESOLVED:

That the City Council go on record extending its deepest sympathy for the family of Barclay Tittmann at this time of such personal loss; and be it further

 

 

RESOLVED:

That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of this resolution to the Tittmann family on behalf of the entire City Council.
